Description: Egyptian terracotta figure of Harpocrates, the infant Horus. Head fragment, broken at neck from a reclining figure. His head is shaven except for his side-lock, and he wears an Egyptian Double Crown flanked by lotus buds held by a ribbon that crosses above his brow. Hollow, from two-piece mould. Possible traces of a very thin white coating or slip. Red-brown Nile silt with abundant mica and white inclusions.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Made in Naukratis at the terracottas workshop there. A number of Harpocrates from the same, or very similar, mould series were found at Naukratis (Gutch 1898-9; 92 n.5, pl.13, no.191; British Museum Bailey 2008, no.3060 GR1886,0401.1442; Bristol H2814; Cambridge NA629; Boston MFA 86.438, possibly 86.461; Brussels, Musées Royaux d’Art et d’Histoire A.1846). Variants of this macrophallic reclining Harpocrates with side knot type has been found in Saqqara as well as the Naukratis workshop area and have been dated to the 3rd and 2nd century BC (Bailey 2008, no. 3058-60). However others have dated good parallels to the Late Hellenistic (Török 1995, no. 72, see no.62) and Roman (1st to 2nd century AD) periods (Fischer 1994, no.575 see also 633; Dunand 1990, nos. 117, 281). Variants have been found at Theadelphia (Weber 1914: no. 60) or unprovenanced (Sotheby’s Sale Catalogue, 18 May 1987, lot 113) and they were making similar examples in a terracotta shop at Memphis (Engelbach et al. 1915, pl. 61, no. 45(1)).
